abstract.text: Provide users quick access to your app’s features from a toolbar and corresponding Touch Bar.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Integrating a Toolbar and Touch Bar into Your App

inlineContent.text: The
toolbar
appears in the space immediately below or next to a window’s title bar and above the app’s content. You use an
object to manage the items that appear in a toolbar, which are
objects created in Interface Builder or source code.
This sample shows you how to add a toolbar to a window and add Touch Bar support that works in conjunction with the toolbar.
The sample defines the custom class
, which derives from
and conforms to the
protocol. In Interface Builder, the sample creates an instance of
in the Window Controller Scene of
, and adds an
object to the
referenced by the controller. Then the sample connects the toolbar’s
to the
instance.
The window controller also defines an outlet variable
, making it possible to reference the toolbar instance in the source code of
Each
object has a unique identifier of type

. AppKit provides identifiers for standard toolbar items such as cloud sharing, printing, and showing the font and color palette. For custom toolbar items, the app provides the identifiers. For example, the sample provides two identifiers for its custom toolbar items: one for setting the font size and one for setting the font style of an
To tell the toolbar which items are available, the sample’s toolbar delegate implements the
method, which returns an array of item identifiers. The available items appear in the toolbar’s customization palette for customizing the toolbar when running the sample app.
When the sample app launches for the first time, a default set of items appear in the toolbar. The sample provides these items by implementing the
delegate method, which returns an array containing the font style and font size item identifiers.

content.text: Create a Toolbar Item from an Identifier

inlineContent.text: The toolbar asks its delegate to create a toolbar item by calling the
method. It calls this method when adding an item to the toolbar but also when adding items to the toolbar’s customization palette.
The sample app’s implementation of this method creates items for the two identifiers created in the app, font style and font size.

code: /** Create a new NSToolbarItem instance and set its attributes based on
toolTip: NSLocalizedString("tool tip font style", comment: ""),
toolTip: NSLocalizedString("tool tip font size", comment: ""),

inlineContent.text: The delegate isn’t responsible for creating toolbar items for standard identifiers; AppKit creates those toolbar items.

content.text: Use a Custom View for a Toolbar Item

inlineContent.text: The font style and font size toolbar items display a custom view that the sample defines in
and connects with outlets in

code: @IBOutlet var styleSegmentView: NSView! // The font style changing view (ends up in an NSToolbarItem).
@IBOutlet var fontSizeView: NSView! // The font size changing view (ends up in an NSToolbarItem).

inlineContent.text: When the toolbar calls the delegate method
, the sample creates the toolbar item by calling its helper function
, passing in the custom view for the requested toolbar item.

code: // Set the right attribute, depending on if we were given an image or a view.
if let image = itemContent as? NSImage {
if let view = itemContent as? NSView {
// We actually need an NSMenuItem here, so we construct one.

content.text: Add More Attributes to a Toolbar Item

inlineContent.text: The sample’s toolbar delegate also implements the
method to know when the toolbar is about to add an item. This gives the delegate the opportunity to add or change state information for the item. For example, the sample sets the
property of a toolbar item with the
identifier.

code: if let addedItem = userInfo["item"] as? NSToolbarItem {

inlineContent.text: The toolbar displays the default items in the same order as they appear in the array that

returns. But users can rearrange the items, add and remove items, and reset the toolbar to its default items by selecting View > Customize Toolbar, which displays the toolbar’s configuration palette. The sample app also saves the changes and reapplies them the next time the user launches the app.
The sample app provides these behaviors by setting the toolbar’s
and
properties to

code: /*	If you pass false here, you turn off the customization palette. The
of the palette, which you can see in Interface Builder is connected
/*	Tell the toolbar that it should save any toolbar configuration changes
to user defaults, that is, persist any mode changes or item reordering.
The app writes the configuration to the app domain using the toolbar

inlineContent.text: The sample app provides Touch Bar support that works in conjunction with the toolbar. Like the toolbar, the app provides two items on the Touch Bar: font style and font size.
Before the sample app can add items to the Touch Bar, it needs to create an
object. The sample does this by overriding the
method, where it creates and returns a new Touch Bar object.
Then, similar to adding toolbar items, the sample implements the
method
, where it creates and returns Touch Bar items for the specified identifier.
It’s possible to simulate a Touch Bar from Xcode by choosing Window > Show Touch Bar.

content.text: Provide Touch Bar Customization to Users

inlineContent.text: As with the toolbar, the sample app lets users customize items in the Touch Bar by choosing View > Customize Touch Bar. The app provides this feature by setting the
property to

code: // Allow users to customize the app's Touch Bar items.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A Boolean value indicating whether the main menu contains an item for customizing the contents of the Touch Bar.
Your custom subclass of the
class should override this method to create and configure your subclass’s default
object.
A view that draws text and handles user interactions with that text.
An object that manages the space above your app’s custom content and either below or integrated with the window’s title bar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether users can modify the contents of the toolbar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the toolbar autosaves its configuration.
The object you use to customize the toolbar contents and configuration.
A set of optional methods you use to configure the toolbar and respond to changes.
Asks the delegate for the toolbar item associated with the specified identifier.
Asks the delegate to provide the items allowed on the toolbar.
Asks the delegate to provide the default items to display on the toolbar.
Tells the delegate that the toolbar is about to add the specified item.
A single item that appears in a window’s toolbar.
Constants for the standard toolbar items that the system provides.
The identifier for a toolbar item that tells your app to print the current document.
The tooltip to display when someone hovers over the item in the toolbar.
An object that provides dynamic contextual controls in the Touch Bar of supported models of MacBook Pro.
A protocol that allows you to provide the items for a bar dynamically.
Asks the delegate object for the bar item for the specified bar and item identifier.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A controller that manages a window, usually a window stored in a nib file.
The window owned by the receiver.
Adopt Touch Bar support by displaying interactive content and controls for your macOS apps.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Creating and Customizing the Touch Bar

abstract.text: Provide a space for controls under a window’s title bar and above your custom content.
Display interactive content and controls in the Touch Bar.
Present your content onscreen and handle user input and events.
